title: What happened to the slaves of Egypt after they built the pyramids? - Quora

response.answer_text: They disappeared back into the imaginations of American fundies. The pyramids were built by a mixture of professional builders, and farmers looking for work during the annual Inundation when their fields would be flooded for months.

Original Question: What happened to the slaves of Egypt after they built the pyramids? The pyramids weren’t built by slaves. That’s a long-outdated view. OK, there were undoubtedly a few slaves among the people involved, however, the vast majority were a mix of professionals - architects, engineers, project planners etc - and seasonal workers, in the main farmers and labourers who couldn’t work the fields during the times that the river Nile was in flood. There was also a veritable army of support workers who looked after the housing and feeding of all the workers.

The pyramids were not built by slaves. Modern scholarly consensus is that the pyramids were built by free laborers, either paid or essentially working off tax obligations. In other words, the pharaohs hired people to build the pyramids, after which the workers went home and got on with their lives.

Well, this is what I have been telling my students for 45 years. Free citizens paid their village taxes to the pharaoh by sending chosen men to labour camps built to house them on the Gaza Plateau These camps have been uncovered by archeologists. Project work took place during the farming “off-season”. A full pyramid project would take about ten years. The workers lives were quite pleasant. They were fed rations of mainly beer, dates and onions. We have contemporary written evidence for this So it seems the slaves, whips and cruelty is very much either a Victorian or Hollywood invention. Still it makes great art and movie epics. You know what they say, “Why spoil a good story”.
Contrary to popular believe, slaves didn’t built the pyramids. Free Egyptian men did, and according with historians they got paid really well for it.

Most Egyptologists argue that the workers who built the Pyramids were paid. They even had graveyards for those who died (the pyramids did take a while to build,) and received danger pay for particularly dangerous jobs. Sorry, the Bible (yet again,) is bollocks.

“What happened to the slaves of Egypt after they built the pyramids?” They all moved to Goshen which, due to plate tectonics, now sits just outside of New York City. From there they spread to surrounding towns and opened up hotels, creating the Borscht Belt.
What slaves? Evidence shows a paid workforce was used and for the time, relatively well taken care of. I hope you arent using mythology from the Bible as historical fact.
